verses.text: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, a servant of the church at Cenchreae,
verses.comment: Paul refers to Phoebe as a servant, or diakonos, of the church. The Greek term can be rendered as 'minister' or 'deacon', possibly indicating an official role. This points to an early structure and order in the church, with women actively serving in ministry.

verses.text: so that you may welcome her in the Lord in a manner worthy of the saints, and help her in whatever matter she may need from you, for she herself has been a benefactor of many, and of myself as well.
verses.comment: Paul urges the believers to support Phoebe, reflecting the Christian duty of hospitality and caring for fellow laborers in ministry.

verses.text: Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Prisca (also called Priscilla) and Aquila were influential early Christians known for their commitment to teaching and assisting the apostles (see Acts 18:2–3).

verses.text: who risked their own necks for my life, to whom not only I give thanks, but also all the churches of the Gentiles.
verses.comment: Prisca and Aquila played vital, sacrificial roles in the safety and mission of Paul, showing the communal nature of the early church's mission.

verses.text: Greet also the church that meets in their house. Greet my beloved Epaenetus, who was the first convert to Christ in Asia.
verses.comment: House churches were central to the early Christian gathering, reflecting the church's beginnings as a close-knit community before formal church buildings.

verses.text: Greet Mary, who has worked very hard for you.
verses.comment: Another exemplary laborer in the faith, Mary is noted for her service—signifying the value of faithful work for the church.

verses.text: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my kinsmen and fellow prisoners; they are well known among the apostles, and they were in Christ before me.
verses.comment: Junia is identified with distinction among apostles, indicating that the church recognized esteemed leaders beyond the Twelve. The mention that they were 'in Christ before me' highlights the continuation and growth of apostolic succession.

verses.text: Greet Ampliatus, my beloved in the Lord.
verses.comment: Paul’s expressions of love reveal the familial nature of Christian fellowship.

verses.text: Greet Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ, and my beloved Stachys.
verses.comment: Paul calls attention to various workers, showing the diversity and cooperation in the ministry.

verses.text: Greet Apelles, who is approved in Christ. Greet those who belong to the household of Aristobulus.
verses.comment: The reference to a household underlines the pattern of entire families and households being baptized and brought into the faith (cf. Acts 16:31–34).

verses.text: Greet Herodion, my kinsman. Greet those of the household of Narcissus, who are in the Lord.
verses.comment: Again household conversions feature, stressing the continuity of faith across family lines.

verses.text: Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, who labor in the Lord. Greet the beloved Persis, who has worked hard in the Lord.
verses.comment: More examples of faithful women working diligently in ministry. The terms for 'labor' and 'work' denote strenuous effort for the life of the church.

verses.text: Greet Rufus, chosen in the Lord, and his mother, who has been a mother to me also.
verses.comment: Rufus may be the same mentioned in Mark 15:21, suggesting early Christian tradition and interconnectedness. Note the close spiritual bonds that go beyond blood-relations.

verses.text: Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers with them.
verses.comment: These greetings to groups and 'brothers' suggest established communities or cells within the greater body of Christ.

verses.text: Greet Philologus, Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.
verses.comment: Paul’s address to 'all the saints' highlights the universal call to holiness among believers.

verses.text: Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ greet you.
verses.comment: The 'holy kiss' was a sign of peace, unity, and reconciliation. Early Christians practiced this, which in time developed into formal liturgical greetings.

verses.text: Now I urge you, brothers, to watch out for those who cause divisions and obstacles contrary to the teaching you have learned; avoid them.
verses.comment: Paul warns against divisiveness and warns the church to hold fast to received teaching, hinting at the need for unity in doctrine and practice for the one church.

verses.text: For such people do not serve our Lord Christ, but their own appetites, and by smooth talk and flattery they deceive the hearts of the innocent.
verses.comment: Guarding against heresy and protecting the faithful is central; Paul affirms the authority placed over doctrine.

verses.text: For your obedience has become known to all. So I rejoice over you, but I want you to be wise about what is good and innocent about what is evil.
verses.comment: Paul encourages both faithfulness and discernment—virtues that protect both belief and conduct in the church.

verses.text: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
verses.comment: This fulfills the promise in Genesis 3:15, previewing Christ’s ultimate victory over evil. The grace of Jesus is central to meeting this spiritual battle.

verses.text: Timothy, my fellow worker, greets you; as do Lucius and Jason and Sosipater, my kinsmen.
verses.comment: Timothy and others are personally present with Paul, showing the close and united leadership of the apostles and their companions.

verses.text: I, Tertius, who wrote down this letter, greet you in the Lord.
verses.comment: Tertius, acting as Paul’s scribe, inserts his own greeting—a reminder of the collaborative nature of Scripture's transmission.

verses.text: Gaius, who is host to me and to the whole church, greets you. Erastus, the city treasurer, and our brother Quartus greet you.
verses.comment: Hospitality is key in the New Testament church. Gaius hosts Paul and the Christian community. Erastus holds a government role, showing early Christian involvement at all levels of society.

verses.text: [Some manuscripts add verse 24: 'The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.']
verses.comment: This verse is omitted in several early manuscripts, but echoes Paul's recurring blessing of grace across his letters, emphasizing the importance of grace as a gift through Christ.

verses.text: Now to him who is able to strengthen you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery kept secret for long ages,
verses.comment: Paul references the proclamation and revelation of Christ as fulfilling God’s secret plan—a reference to the unity and continuity of God’s work throughout history, now revealed in Jesus.

verses.text: but now revealed and made known through the prophetic Scriptures, according to the command of the eternal God, to bring about the obedience of faith among all nations—
verses.comment: The 'obedience of faith' resonates with the necessity for both belief and obedience—faith is never merely intellectual but leads to action. The unity of Old and New Testaments is emphasized.

verses.text: to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, be glory forever! Amen.
verses.comment: Paul closes with doxology, emphasizing God’s wisdom revealed in Christ. This final verse encapsulates the glorification of God through the unfolding of salvation history and the role of Christ at the center of it. The emphasis on tradition, unity, and apostolic authority subtly underscores the ongoing structure of the Church Christ established.
